title:
An Implicit Function Method for Computing the Stability Boundaries of
  Hill's Equation
abstract:
Hill's equation is a common model of a time-periodic system that can undergo
parametric resonance for certain choices of system parameters. For most kinds
of parametric forcing, stable regions in its two-dimensional parameter space
need to be identified numerically, typically by applying a matrix trace
criterion. By integrating ODEs derived from the stability criterion, we present
an alternative, more accurate and computationally efficient numerical method
for determining the stability boundaries of Hill's equation in parameter space.
This method works similarly to determine stability boundaries for the closely
related problem of vibrational stabilization of the linearized Katpiza
pendulum. Additionally, we derive a stability criterion for the damped Hill's
equation in terms of a matrix trace criterion on an equivalent undamped system.
In doing so we generalize the method of this paper to compute stability
boundaries for parametric resonance in the presence of damping.
subjects: Electrical Engineering and Systems Science/Systems and Control
